chapterMetadata.title: A Letter to God
chapterMetadata.author: G.L. Fuentes
chapterMetadata.subject: English
learningObjectives: To understand the themes of faith, hope, and human nature
To analyze character development and motivation
To identify literary devices like irony and metaphor
To enhance vocabulary through contextual learning
To practice grammar concepts like relative clauses and negatives for emphasis

beforeYouRead.introduction: They say faith can move mountains. But what should we put our faith in? This is the question this story delicately poses. Lencho is a farmer who writes a letter to God when his crops are ruined, asking for a hundred pesos.
thinkingQuestions: Does God send him the money?
What would your answers to these questions be?
How do you think the story continues?

characters.name: Lencho
characters.description: A hardworking farmer with unwavering faith in God, described as 'an ox of a man' who works like an animal in the fields but knows how to write.

characters.name: Lencho's Wife
characters.description: A supportive woman who prepares meals and shares her husband's concerns about their livelihood.

characters.name: The Postmaster
characters.description: A kind, amiable man who is moved by Lencho's faith and decides to help him without shaking his belief in God.

characters.name: Post Office Employees
characters.description: Workers who contribute money to help Lencho, showing human compassion and solidarity.

storySummary: A Letter to God tells the story of Lencho, a poor farmer whose crops are destroyed by a hailstorm. In his desperation and unwavering faith, he writes a letter to God asking for a hundred pesos to replant his crops. The postmaster, moved by Lencho's faith, collects money from his employees and friends to send to Lencho. However, when Lencho receives only seventy pesos instead of the hundred he requested, he writes another letter to God, blaming the post office employees for stealing the missing thirty pesos. The story explores themes of faith, irony, and human nature.

themes.name: Faith and Belief
themes.description: Lencho's unshakeable faith in God drives the entire narrative. His complete trust in divine intervention reflects both the power and potential blindness of absolute faith.

themes.name: Irony
themes.description: The central irony lies in Lencho's reaction to receiving help - he blames the very people who helped him, showing how sometimes good deeds can be misunderstood.

themes.name: Human Compassion vs. Ingratitude
themes.description: The postmaster and employees show genuine kindness, while Lencho's response reveals how preconceived notions can prevent us from recognizing human goodness.

themes.name: Nature's Power
themes.description: The destructive hailstorm represents nature's unpredictable force and how it affects human lives, especially those dependent on agriculture.

storySections.title: The Setting and Hope for Rain
content: The house — the only one in the entire valley — sat on the crest of a low hill. From this height one could see the river and the field of ripe corn dotted with the flowers that always promised a good harvest.
The only thing the earth needed was a downpour or at least a shower. Throughout the morning Lencho — who knew his fields intimately — had done nothing else but see the sky towards the north-east.

'Now we're really going to get some water, woman.' The woman who was preparing supper, replied, 'Yes, God willing'. The older boys were working in the field, while the smaller ones were playing near the house until the woman called to them all, 'Come for dinner'.
oralComprehensionCheck: Why did Lencho say the raindrops were like 'new coins'?
How did the rain change? What happened to Lencho's fields?
What were Lencho's feelings when the hail stopped?

storySections.title: The Storm and Destruction
content: It was during the meal that, just as Lencho had predicted, big drops of rain began to fall. In the north-east huge mountains of clouds could be seen approaching. The air was fresh and sweet.

The man went out for no other reason than to have the pleasure of feeling the rain on his body, and when he returned he exclaimed, 'These aren't raindrops falling from the sky, they are new coins. The big drops are ten cent pieces and the little ones are fives.'

With a satisfied expression he regarded the field of ripe corn with its flowers, draped in a curtain of rain. But suddenly a strong wind began to blow and along with the rain very large hailstones began to fall. These truly did resemble new silver coins. The boys, exposing themselves to the rain, ran out to collect the frozen pearls.

'It's really getting bad now,' exclaimed the man. 'I hope it passes quickly.' It did not pass quickly. For an hour the hail rained on the house, the garden, the hillside, the cornfield, on the whole valley.
The field was white, as if covered with salt. Not a leaf remained on the trees. The corn was totally destroyed. The flowers were gone from the plants. Lencho's soul was filled with sadness.
When the storm had passed, he stood in the middle of the field and said to his sons, 'A plague of locusts would have left more than this. The hail has left nothing. This year we will have no corn.'

wordMeanings.definition: insects which fly in big swarms (groups) and destroy crops

oralComprehensionCheck: Why did Lencho say the raindrops were like 'new coins'?
How did the rain change? What happened to Lencho's fields?
What were Lencho's feelings when the hail stopped?

storySections.title: The Letter to God
content: That night was a sorrowful one. 'All our work, for nothing.' 'There's no one who can help us.' 'We'll all go hungry this year.'
But in the hearts of all who lived in that solitary house in the middle of the valley, there was a single hope: help from God.
'Don't be so upset, even though this seems like a total loss. Remember, no one dies of hunger.' 'That's what they say: no one dies of hunger.'
All through the night, Lencho thought only of his one hope: the help of God, whose eyes, as he had been instructed, see everything, even what is deep in one's conscience.

Lencho was an ox of a man, working like an animal in the fields, but still he knew how to write. The following Sunday, at daybreak, he began to write a letter which he himself would carry to town and place in the mail. It was nothing less than a letter to God.
'God,' he wrote, 'if you don't help me, my family and I will go hungry this year. I need a hundred pesos in order to sow my field again and to live until the crop comes, because the hailstorm....'
He wrote 'To God' on the envelope, put the letter inside and, still troubled, went to town. At the post office, he placed a stamp on the letter and dropped it into the mailbox.

wordMeanings.definition: an inner sense of right and wrong
currency of several Latin American countries

oralComprehensionCheck: Who or what did Lencho have faith in? What did he do?
What did the postmaster do then?

storySections.title: The Postmaster's Response
content: One of the employees, who was a postman and also helped at the post office, went to his boss laughing heartily and showed him the letter to God. Never in his career as a postman had he known that address.

The postmaster — a fat, amiable fellow — also broke out laughing, but almost immediately he turned serious and, tapping the letter on his desk, commented, 'What faith! I wish I had the faith of the man who wrote this letter. Starting up a correspondence with God!'

So, in order not to shake the writer's faith in God, the postmaster came up with an idea: answer the letter. But when he opened it, it was evident that to answer it he needed something more than goodwill, ink and paper.
But he stuck to his resolution: he asked for money from his employees, he himself gave part of his salary, and several friends of his were obliged to give something 'for an act of charity'.

It was impossible for him to gather together the hundred pesos, so he was able to send the farmer only a little more than half. He put the money in an envelope addressed to Lencho and with it a letter containing only a single word as a signature: God.

wordMeanings.definition: help given to those in need

storySections.title: Lencho's Second Letter
content: The following Sunday Lencho came a bit earlier than usual to ask if there was a letter for him. It was the postman himself who handed the letter to him while the postmaster, experiencing the contentment of a man who has performed a good deed, looked on from his office.

Lencho showed not the slightest surprise on seeing the money; such was his confidence — but he became angry when he counted the money. God could not have made a mistake, nor could he have denied Lencho what he had requested.

Immediately, Lencho went up to the window to ask for paper and ink. On the public writing-table, he started to write, with much wrinkling of his brow, caused by the effort he had to make to express his ideas.
When he finished, he went to the window to buy a stamp which he licked and then affixed to the envelope with a blow of his fist.

The moment the letter fell into the mailbox the postmaster went to open it. It said: 'God: Of the money that I asked for, only seventy pesos reached me. Send me the rest, since I need it very much. But don't send it to me through the mail because the post office employees are a bunch of crooks. Lencho.'
oralComprehensionCheck: Was Lencho surprised to find a letter for him with money in it?

thinkingAboutText.question: Who does Lencho have complete faith in? Which sentences in the story tell you this?
Why does the postmaster send money to Lencho? Why does he sign the letter 'God'?
Did Lencho try to find out who had sent the money to him? Why/Why not?
Who does Lencho think has taken the rest of the money? What is the irony in the situation?
hints: Remember that the irony of a situation is an unexpected aspect of it
An ironic situation is strange or amusing because it is the opposite of what is expected

thinkingAboutText.question: Are there people like Lencho in the real world? What kind of a person would you say he is?
hints: Consider words like: greedy, naive, stupid, ungrateful, selfish, comical, unquestioning

thinkingAboutText.question: There are two kinds of conflict in the story: between humans and nature, and between humans themselves. How are these conflicts illustrated?

vocabularyExercises.title: Storm Names
vocabularyExercises.instructions: There are different names in different parts of the world for storms, depending on their nature. Match the names with their descriptions and fill in the blanks.
sentences: A violent tropical storm in which strong winds move in a circle: c _ c _ _ _ _
A violent tropical storm with very strong winds: t _ p _ _ _ _
A violent storm whose centre is a cloud in the shape of a funnel: t _ r _ _ _ _
A violent storm with very strong winds, especially in the western Atlantic Ocean: h _ r _ _ _ _ _ _
A very strong wind that moves very fast in a spinning movement and causes a lot of damage: w _ _ r _ _ _ _ _

vocabularyExercises.title: Understanding 'Hope'
vocabularyExercises.instructions: Match the sentences in Column A with the meanings of 'hope' in Column B.
columnA: Will you get the subjects you want to study in college? I hope so.
I hope you don't mind my saying this, but I don't like the way you are arguing.
This discovery will give new hope to HIV/AIDS sufferers.
We were hoping against hope that the judges would not notice our mistakes.
I called early in the hope of speaking to her before she went to school.
Just when everybody had given up hope, the fishermen came back, seven days after the cyclone.
columnB: a feeling that something good will probably happen
thinking that this would happen (It may or may not have happened.)
stopped believing that this good thing would happen
wanting something to happen (and thinking it quite possible)
showing concern that what you say should not offend or disturb the other person: a way of being polite
wishing for something to happen, although this is very unlikely

vocabularyExercises.title: Metaphors in the Story
vocabularyExercises.instructions: Complete the table by finding metaphors from the story and explaining what qualities are being compared.

terms.definition: Clouds compared to mountains for their massive size and imposing presence
terms.example: The mass or 'hugeness' of clouds like mountains

terms.definition: Raindrops compared to coins for their value and preciousness to the farmer
terms.example: The value and importance of rain to agriculture

terms.definition: Hailstones compared to silver coins for their appearance and shine
terms.example: The round, shiny appearance of hailstones

terms.definition: Hailstones compared to pearls for their beauty and roundness
terms.example: The precious, round appearance of hailstones

terms.definition: The hailstorm compared to a locust plague for its destructive power
Lencho compared to an ox for his strength and hardworking nature
terms.example: Physical strength and tireless work capacity

grammarTopics.title: Relative Clauses
grammarTopics.explanation: Relative clauses give us more information about a person or thing. They begin with relative pronouns like who, whom, whose, and which. Non-defining relative clauses are used when we already know the identity of the person or thing being described.
examplesFromText: All morning Lencho — who knew his fields intimately — looked at the sky.
The woman, who was preparing supper, replied, 'Yes, God willing.'
One of the employees, who was a postman and also helped at the post office, went to his boss.

exercises.instruction: Join the sentences using who, whom, whose, which, as suggested.
items: I often go to Mumbai. Mumbai is the commercial capital of India. (which)
My mother is going to host a TV show on cooking. She cooks very well. (who)
These sportspersons are going to meet the President. Their performance has been excellent. (whose)
Lencho prayed to God. His eyes see into our minds. (whose)
This man cheated me. I trusted him. (whom)

grammarTopics.title: Using Negatives for Emphasis
grammarTopics.explanation: Sometimes negative words are used not just to show absence or contradiction, but to emphasize an idea. This makes the statement stronger and more impactful.
examplesFromText: Lencho…had done nothing else but see the sky towards the north-east. (He had done only this)
The man went out for no other reason than to have the pleasure of feeling the rain on his body. (He had only this reason)
Lencho showed not the slightest surprise on seeing the money. (He showed no surprise at all)

exercises.instruction: Find sentences in the story with negative words that express the following ideas emphatically:
items: The trees lost all their leaves.
The letter was addressed to God himself.
The postman saw this address for the first time in his career.

writingActivities.title: Creative Writing - Alternative Ending
writingActivities.instructions: Imagine if Lencho had realized that the post office employees had helped him. Write an alternative ending to the story showing how he might have reacted.
prompts: What would Lencho say to the postmaster?
How would this change his faith in humanity?
Would he still write letters to God?

writingActivities.title: Character Analysis
writingActivities.instructions: Write a character sketch of either Lencho or the postmaster, analyzing their personality, motivations, and role in the story.
prompts: What are their strengths and weaknesses?
How do they change throughout the story?

writingActivities.title: Poster Design
writingActivities.instructions: Design a poster for your area on how to save water during summer and when it is available in excess. Consider the water-related issues faced by Lencho and relate them to current environmental concerns.
prompts: What water conservation methods can you suggest?
How can communities prepare for droughts and floods?

speakingActivities.title: Personal Experience Sharing
speakingActivities.description: Have you ever been in great difficulty, and felt that only a miracle could help you? How was your problem solved? Speak about this in class with your teacher.
instructions: Think of a challenging situation you've faced
Explain what made it seem impossible to solve
Describe how the problem was eventually resolved
Reflect on what you learned from the experience

speakingActivities.title: Debate - Faith vs. Logic
speakingActivities.description: Organize a class debate on whether Lencho's approach to solving his problem was right or wrong.
instructions: Form two teams - one supporting Lencho, one critiquing him
Prepare arguments based on the story
Consider different perspectives on faith and practical action

listeningActivities.title: Letter Reading Activity
listeningActivities.description: Listen to the sample letter read out by your teacher. As you listen, fill in the information about who is writing to whom and other details.
comprehensionQuestions: Where and when were they last together?
What has the writer sent to the reader?
In which month was it sent?
What was the reason for not writing earlier?

personalities.name: Lencho
personalities.description:
Lencho is a hardworking farmer with unwavering faith in God from the story 'A Letter to God' by G.L. Fuentes. He lives in a valley with his family and depends entirely on his crops for survival. When a devastating hailstorm destroys his cornfield, Lencho doesn't lose hope but instead writes a letter directly to God asking for 100 pesos to replant his crops.

Lencho represents absolute faith and trust in divine providence. He is described as 'an ox of a man' - strong, hardworking, and determined. Despite being a simple farmer, he knows how to read and write. His faith is so pure and unshakeable that when he receives only 70 pesos (sent by kind post office employees), he doesn't doubt God but instead believes the postal workers stole the remaining 30 pesos.

Lencho can discuss:
- The importance of faith in difficult times
- Agricultural challenges and dependency on weather
- The relationship between hard work and divine help
- How innocent trust can sometimes blind us to human kindness
- The struggle of rural farmers and their connection to nature
- Writing letters as a form of communication and prayer
- The irony of his situation - receiving help but not recognizing it
- His family life and the responsibilities of being the provider
- The difference between expecting miracles and working for solutions
- Why he trusted God completely but suspected fellow humans

Lencho speaks with simple, heartfelt language, often referencing God, farming, and his family's needs. He sees everything through the lens of his faith and his farming experience.
